meanings.def: the part or side of something that faces forward; the side of something that you look at first
examples: The front of the building was covered with ivy.
The front of the car was badly damaged.
on the front The book has a picture of Rome on the front.
up the front The jacket zips up the front.
down the front a green sleeveless top which buttons down the front
Check the position of the pockets on the jacket front.
I usually end up with gravy down my shirt front.
She stared into the large mirror, running her hands down the front of her dress.
The dress is embroidered at the neck and down the front.
They run an annual competition for tidy shop and house fronts.
The drawer fronts are made of solid mahogany.

meanings.def: the position that is directly ahead of somebody/something
examples: I turned round to face the front.
Keep your eyes to the front and walk straight ahead.
at the front of something There's a garden at the front of the house.

meanings.def: the part of something that is furthest forward
examples: The singer came to the front of the stage.
The teacher made me move my seat to the front of the classroom.
at the front She always sits at the front.
at the front of something Put your fare into the box at the front of the bus.
in the front I prefer to travel in the front (= next to the driver in a car).
in the front of something Write your name in the front of the book (= the first few pages).
to the front (of something) The dining room is to the front of the house.
I’ll meet you in front of/​outside your hotel.
There’s a bus stop in front of the house (= on the same side of the road).
There’s a bus stop opposite the house (= on the other side of the road).
The driver sits at the front of the bus.
Put the shortest flowers in the front (of the bunch).

meanings.def: the part of somebody’s body that faces forwards
examples: on your front She was lying on her front.
down your front I spilled coffee down my front.

meanings.def: the side of a large building, especially a church, that faces west, north, etc.
examples: the west front of the cathedral

meanings.def: the road or area of land along the edge of the sea, a lake or a river
examples: Couples walked hand in hand along the front.

meanings.def: an area where fighting takes place during a war
examples: More British troops have been sent to the front.
to serve at the front
fighting a war on two fronts
Reports from the battle fronts became briefer and vaguer.
Even young teenagers were sent to the front.
Thousands were killed on the eastern front.

meanings.def: a particular area of activity
examples: on the… front Things are looking unsettled on the economic front.
Things should get a little easier on the work front soon.
Progress has been made on all fronts.

meanings.def: behaviour that is not what it appears to be, done in order to hide somebody's true feelings or opinions
examples: It's not always easy to put on a brave front for the family.
front for something Rudeness is just a front for her shyness.
She put on a brave front, but I knew how miserable she was.
Without that false front, I wouldn't be able to face the world.

meanings.def: a person or an organization that is used to hide an illegal or secret activity
examples: The travel company is just a front for drug trafficking.

meanings.def: used in the names of some political organizations
examples: the Animal Liberation Front

meanings.def: the line where a mass of cold air meets a mass of warm air
examples: a cold/warm front

meanings.def: if you put on a piece of clothing back to front, you make a mistake and put the back where the front should be
examples: I think you've got that sweater on back to front.

meanings.def: in somebody’s presence; in front of somebody
examples: He had seen his life's work destroyed before his very eyes.
Before our very eyes, the bird snatched the fish from the plate and flew off.

meanings.def: with immediate payment of cash
examples: to pay for something cash up front

meanings.def: to show people that all members of a group have the same opinion about things
examples: The prime minister stressed the need to present a united front.

meanings.def: in or into the most important position
examples: The issue has moved front and center in his presidential campaign.

meanings.def: in a position that is further forward than somebody/something but not very far away
examples: Their house is the one with the big garden in front.

meanings.def: in first place in a race or competition
examples: The blue team is currently in front with a lead of six points.

meanings.def: in a position that is further forward than somebody/something but not very far away
examples: The car in front of me stopped suddenly and I had to brake.
The bus stops right in front of our house.
He was standing in front of me in the line.
She is now entitled to put ‘Professor’ in front of her name.

meanings.def: in a position facing somebody/something
examples: to perform in front of a big crowd/audience
She spends all day sitting in front of (= working at) her computer.
She's a natural in front of the camera (= being filmed/photographed).

meanings.def: if you do something in front of somebody, you do it when they are there
examples: Please don't talk about it in front of the children.

meanings.def: still to come; not yet passed
examples: Don't give up. You still have your whole life in front of you.

meanings.def: to take an active part in what you are telling or persuading others to do
in the part of a theatre, restaurant, etc. where the public sits
examples: There's only a small audience out front tonight.
He cooked while she sat out front and waited tables.

meanings.def: in the area near to the entrance to a building
examples: I’ll wait for you out (the) front.

meanings.def: as payment in advance
examples: We'll pay you half up front and the other half when you've finished the job.

meanings.def: in a forward position
examples: to play up front

idioms.def: if you put on a piece of clothing back to front, you make a mistake and put the back where the front should be
examples: I think you've got that sweater on back to front.

idioms.def: in somebody’s presence; in front of somebody
examples: He had seen his life's work destroyed before his very eyes.
Before our very eyes, the bird snatched the fish from the plate and flew off.
to pay for something cash up front

idioms.idiom: form, present, etc. a united front
idioms.def: to show people that all members of a group have the same opinion about things
examples: The prime minister stressed the need to present a united front.

idioms.def: in or into the most important position
examples: The issue has moved front and center in his presidential campaign.

idioms.def: in a position that is further forward than somebody/something but not very far away
examples: Their house is the one with the big garden in front.
The blue team is currently in front with a lead of six points.

idioms.def: in a position that is further forward than somebody/something but not very far away
examples: The car in front of me stopped suddenly and I had to brake.
The bus stops right in front of our house.
He was standing in front of me in the line.
She is now entitled to put ‘Professor’ in front of her name.
to perform in front of a big crowd/audience
She spends all day sitting in front of (= working at) her computer.
She's a natural in front of the camera (= being filmed/photographed).
Please don't talk about it in front of the children.
Don't give up. You still have your whole life in front of you.

idioms.def: to take an active part in what you are telling or persuading others to do
in the part of a theatre, restaurant, etc. where the public sits
examples: There's only a small audience out front tonight.
He cooked while she sat out front and waited tables.
I’ll wait for you out (the) front.
We'll pay you half up front and the other half when you've finished the job.
to play up front

meanings.def: on or at the front of something
examples: (British English) the front garden
(North American English) the front yard
the front wheels of the car
the front cover of the book
We had seats in the front row.
an animal’s front legs
front teeth
a front-seat passenger

meanings.def: produced with the front of the tongue in a higher position than the back, for example /iː/ in English
being given a lot of attention because it is considered important
examples: Anything that keeps education on the front burner is good.

meanings.def: at an advantage
examples: They allowed the home side to get on the front foot right at the start.

meanings.def: taking positive steps to achieve something
examples: He has been firmly on the front foot, calling for politicians and police to intervene.

idioms.def: being given a lot of attention because it is considered important
examples: Anything that keeps education on the front burner is good.
They allowed the home side to get on the front foot right at the start.
He has been firmly on the front foot, calling for politicians and police to intervene.

meanings.def: to face something or be in front of something; to have the front pointing towards something
examples: front something The cathedral fronts the city's main square.
front onto something The line of houses fronted straight onto the road.

meanings.def: having the front made of or covered with something
examples: a glass-fronted bookcase

meanings.def: to lead or represent an organization, a group, etc.
examples: He fronts a multinational company.
A former art student fronted the band (= was the main singer).
The band is fronted by former art student, Jim Oliver.

meanings.def: to present a television programme, a show, etc.
examples: The former footballer will front a new television sports quiz.

meanings.def: to give more importance to a part of a sentence by placing it at or near the beginning of the sentence, as in ‘That I would like to see.’
